svg.text: Investigating the Role of Ras Signaling

div.style: font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif; font-size: 10px; text-align: justify; line-height: 1.4;

foreignObject.div: This study investigates the role of Ras signaling in Drosophila melanogaster eye development using genetic crosses and microscopy techniques. We demonstrate that constitutively active Ras leads to overgrowth and disruption of ommatidial patterning, while dominant negative Ras results in reduced eye size and developmental defects.

div.style: font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif; font-size: 10px; text-align: justify; line-height: 1.4;

foreignObject.div: The Ras signaling pathway plays a crucial role in regulating cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival across species. In Drosophila melanogaster, this pathway is particularly important during eye development, where it coordinates the precise patterning of ommatidia...

svg.text: Figure 1: Comparison of wild-type and Ras mutant Drosophila eyes
